elements.content: The synthesis, crystal structure, and sorption properties of [Cu2(bdc)2(dmf)]H2O·(dmf)(C2H5OH)0.5 (2·g, g = dmf·H2O·(C2H5OH)0.5, bdc = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, dmf = N,N‘-dimethylformamide) are reported. 2·g features upended bowl cavities with an outer diameter of 9.4 Å, which are enclosed by four tetracarboxylate-bridged Cu2 paddle-wheels and extended by dicarboxylate linkers into a two-dimensional (2-D) coordination polymer. The metal−organic layers are further stacked in a slipped manner through van der Waals interactions to generate a three-dimensional (3-D) supramolecular structure having 2-D channels that accommodate the solvent molecules. After removal of the solvent molecules, solid 2 exhibits permanent porosity verified by an N2 sorption isotherm with a Langmuir surface area of 629 m2·g-1 and Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of 374 m2·g-1. Moreover, solid 2 also displays interesting methanol and benzene vapor sorption behaviors with large hysteresis and incomplete desorption, which is attributed to the chemisorption.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis, crystal structure, and sorption properties of [Cu2(bdc)2(dmf)]H2O⋅(dmf)(C2H5OH)0.5 (2⋅g, g = dmf⋅H2O⋅(C2H5OH)0.5, bdc = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, dmf = N,N‘-dimethylformamide) are reported. 2⋅g features upended bowl cavities with an outer diameter of 9.4 Å, which are enclosed by four tetracarboxylate-bridged Cu2 paddle-wheels and extended by dicarboxylate linkers into a two-dimensional (2-D) coordination polymer. The metal-organic layers are further stacked in a slipped manner through van der Waals interactions to generate a three-dimensional (3-D) supramolecular structure having 2-D channels that accommodate the solvent molecules. After removal of the solvent molecules, solid 2 exhibits permanent porosity verified by an N2 sorption isotherm with a Langmuir surface area of 629 m2⋅g-1 and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 374 m2⋅g-1. Moreover, solid 2 also displays interesting methanol and benzene vapor sorption behaviors with large hysteresis and incomplete desorption, which is attributed to the chemisorption.

elements.content: Reaction of Cu(II) and 1,3-benzenecarboxylate generated a porous, layered coordination polymer featuring bowl-shaped cavities and coordinatively unsaturated metal centers upon removal of the guest and labile apically ligating solvent molecules, which shows unique sorption behaviors.
elements.clean_text: Reaction of Cu(II) and 1,3-benzenecarboxylate generated a porous, layered coordination polymer featuring bowl-shaped cavities and coordinatively unsaturated metal centers upon removal of the guest and labile apically ligating solvent molecules, which shows unique sorption behaviors.

elements.content: Recently, porous coordination polymers have been thrust into the limelight because of their intriguing structures and potential applicability as functional materials in many areas such as storage, exchange, and catalysis. Since the high stability of the coordination framework is essential for many practical applications, investigation into the formation of highly porous and stable rigid three-dimensional (3-D) frameworks has been actively engaged by using stiff bridging ligands. In contrast, flexible host frameworks based on coordination bonds, as well as those associated with weaker hydrogen bonds, π−π stacking, and/or other supramolecular interactions, may have a higher selectivity for guest inclusion and exhibit structural transformation on the adsorption or the desorption of guest molecules and are now recognized as a new class of functional materials or the so-called third-generation compounds. A number of such kinds of flexible porous materials have been described by Kitagawa and co-workers recently. In addition, coordinatively unsaturated metal centers in porous coordination polymers are important because they may induce shape- and/or size-selectivity toward guest molecules and are expected to be effective heterogeneous catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, porous coordination polymers have been thrust into the limelight because of their intriguing structures and potential applicability as functional materials in many areas such as storage, exchange, and catalysis. Since the high stability of the coordination framework is essential for many practical applications, investigation into the formation of highly porous and stable rigid three-dimensional (3-D) frameworks has been actively engaged by using stiff bridging ligands. In contrast, flexible host frameworks based on coordination bonds, as well as those associated with weaker hydrogen bonds, π-π stacking, and/or other supramolecular interactions, may have a higher selectivity for guest inclusion and exhibit structural transformation on the adsorption or the desorption of guest molecules and are now recognized as a new class of functional materials or the so-called third-generation compounds. A number of such kinds of flexible porous materials have been described by Kitagawa and co-workers recently. In addition, coordinatively unsaturated metal centers in porous coordination polymers are important because they may induce shape- and/or size-selectivity toward guest molecules and are expected to be effective heterogeneous catalysts.

elements.content: To provide coordinatively unsaturated metal centers, Cu(II) is promising since it can display a Jahn−Teller distortion and provide an open metal site by facile removal of the apically coordinated volatile molecules. Zawarotko and co-workers have reported a novel 2-D coordination polymer based on Cu(II) and H2bdc, namely, [Cu2(bdc)2(py)2]4·xbenzene/py (1) (H2bdc = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate acid; py = pyridine), which exhibits nanometer-size [Cu2(bdc)2(py)2]4 bowls, each being constructed by four tetra(carboxylate)-bridged Cu(II) dimers as the secondary building units (SBUs). The metal−organic layers in 1 are orderly packed in an AAA manner to generate one-dimensional (1-D), hourglass-shaped channels between adjacent bowls, where the guest benzene/py molecules are accommodated. However, the guest molecules in 1 cannot be freely released due to the obstruction of the strong and large apical py ligands in the SBUs, although the layers are expected to very stable. Therefore, 1 did not exhibit gas sorption properties. Presumably, by replacement of the py ligands with small and labile apical ligands, we may be able to construct layered porous materials having open channels for gas sorption.
elements.clean_text: To provide coordinatively unsaturated metal centers, Cu(II) is promising since it can display a Jahn-Teller distortion and provide an open metal site by facile removal of the apically coordinated volatile molecules. Zawarotko and co-workers have reported a novel 2-D coordination polymer based on Cu(II) and H2bdc, namely, [Cu2(bdc)2(py)2]4⋅xbenzene/py (1) (H2bdc = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate acid; py = pyridine), which exhibits nanometer-size [Cu2(bdc)2(py)2]4 bowls, each being constructed by four tetra(carboxylate)-bridged Cu(II) dimers as the secondary building units (SBUs). The metal-organic layers in 1 are orderly packed in an AAA manner to generate one-dimensional (1-D), hourglass-shaped channels between adjacent bowls, where the guest benzene/py molecules are accommodated. However, the guest molecules in 1 cannot be freely released due to the obstruction of the strong and large apical py ligands in the SBUs, although the layers are expected to very stable. Therefore, 1 did not exhibit gas sorption properties. Presumably, by replacement of the py ligands with small and labile apical ligands, we may be able to construct layered porous materials having open channels for gas sorption.

elements.content: Following the above consideration, we are able to construct a new, laminated copper(II) coordination polymer with bdc, formulated empirically as [Cu2(bdc)2(dmf)](dmf)·H2O·(C2H5OH)0.5 (2·g). As expected, the metal−organic layers in 2·g are structurally analogous to those in 1 and are stacked in a slipped manner through van der Waals interactions to generate a 3-D supramolecular framework with well-defined microporosity and active metal centers, thus exhibiting unique sorption behaviors.
elements.clean_text: Following the above consideration, we are able to construct a new, laminated copper(II) coordination polymer with bdc, formulated empirically as [Cu2(bdc)2(dmf)](dmf)⋅H2O⋅(C2H5OH)0.5 (2⋅g). As expected, the metal-organic layers in 2⋅g are structurally analogous to those in 1 and are stacked in a slipped manner through van der Waals interactions to generate a 3-D supramolecular framework with well-defined microporosity and active metal centers, thus exhibiting unique sorption behaviors.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. All solvent and starting materials for synthesis were purchased commercially and were used as received. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Bruker TENSOR 27 Fourier Transform Infrared spectrometer in the 400−4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed at a rate of 5 °C/min under N2 using a NETZSCH TG 209 system. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. All solvent and starting materials for synthesis were purchased commercially and were used as received. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Bruker TENSOR 27 Fourier Transform Infrared spectrometer in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed at a rate of 5 °C/min under N2 using a NETZSCH TG 209 system. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffractometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of 2·g. An aqueous solution (15 mL) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.122 g, 0.5 mmol) was added to a 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) in a dmf and ethanol mixture (1:1, 30 mL) in the presence of benzimidazole (0.030 g, 0.25 mmol). The resulting solution was filtered and allowed to stand at room temperature. Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after several days (Yield 59%). C23H27Cu2N2O11.5 (642.56):  calcd. C, 42.99; H, 4.24; N, 4.36%. Found:  C, 42.45; H, 4.12; N, 4.54%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3424(w), 2930(w), 1632(vs), 1577(m), 1389(vs), 1104(m), 723(m), 488(m).
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 2⋅g. An aqueous solution (15 mL) of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.122 g, 0.5 mmol) was added to a 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) in a dmf and ethanol mixture (1:1, 30 mL) in the presence of benzimidazole (0.030 g, 0.25 mmol). The resulting solution was filtered and allowed to stand at room temperature. Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after several days (Yield 59%). C23H27Cu2N2O11.5 (642.56): calcd. C, 42.99; H, 4.24; N, 4.36%. Found: C, 42.45; H, 4.12; N, 4.54%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3424(w), 2930(w), 1632(vs), 1577(m), 1389(vs), 1104(m), 723(m), 488(m).

elements.content:
Synthesis of 2·4H2O. This compound was produced by exposing desolvated 2 in open air for about 4 h.

TGA and PXRD Characterization. From the TGA results, we found that the observed weight loss (19.6%) at 238 °C for 2·g is reasonably close to calculated values based on elemental analysis (17.8%), corresponding to the removal of guest dmf and water molecules, as well as to the apical water and ethanol ligands (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The PXRD pattern of as-synthesized 2·g is consistent with that simulated using the single-crystal data of 2·g, which confirms the phase purity of the bulk sample of 2·g (Figure S2, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 2⋅4H2O. This compound was produced by exposing desolvated 2 in open air for about 4 h. 

 TGA and PXRD Characterization. From the TGA results, we found that the observed weight loss (19.6%) at 238 °C for 2⋅g is reasonably close to calculated values based on elemental analysis (17.8%), corresponding to the removal of guest dmf and water molecules, as well as to the apical water and ethanol ligands (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The PXRD pattern of as-synthesized 2⋅g is consistent with that simulated using the single-crystal data of 2⋅g, which confirms the phase purity of the bulk sample of 2⋅g (Figure S2, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Sorption Measurements. The sorption isotherm for N2 gas was measured with an automatic volumetric adsorption apparatus (Micrometrics ASAP 2010) at 77 K, and the sorption isotherms for methanol and benzene vapors were measured with an automatic gravimetric adsorption apparatus (IGA-003 series, Hiden Isochema Ltd) at 298 K. The as-synthesized samples (weight 250−300 mg) were placed in a quartz tube and dried under high vacuum at 393 K for 12 h to remove the solvent molecules prior to measurements.
elements.clean_text: Sorption Measurements. The sorption isotherm for N2 gas was measured with an automatic volumetric adsorption apparatus (Micrometrics ASAP 2010) at 77 K, and the sorption isotherms for methanol and benzene vapors were measured with an automatic gravimetric adsorption apparatus (IGA-003 series, Hiden Isochema Ltd) at 298 K. The as-synthesized samples (weight 250-300 mg) were placed in a quartz tube and dried under high vacuum at 393 K for 12 h to remove the solvent molecules prior to measurements.

elements.content: Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement. Crystal data and details of the data collection and refinement for 2·g and 2·4H2O are summarized in Table . The selected bond lengths and bond angles of 2·g are listed in Table . X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD system with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 150 and 293 K, respectively. Absorption corrections were applied by SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters except the disordered solvent molecules. The solvent molecules in 2·4H2O were highly disordered. Efforts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were in vain. The SQUEEZE routine was used to remove the scattering from the highly disordered solvent molecules. The structure of 2·4H2O was then refined again using the new intensity data generated by SQUEEZE. Statistics prior to treatment of data with SQUEEZE were R1 = 0.1262 (I > 2σ(I)), wR2 = 0.3422 (all data), and S = 1.122.
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement. Crystal data and details of the data collection and refinement for 2⋅g and 2⋅4H2O are summarized in Table . The selected bond lengths and bond angles of 2⋅g are listed in Table . X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD system with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 150 and 293 K, respectively. Absorption corrections were applied by SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters except the disordered solvent molecules. The solvent molecules in 2⋅4H2O were highly disordered. Efforts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were in vain. The SQUEEZE routine was used to remove the scattering from the highly disordered solvent molecules. The structure of 2⋅4H2O was then refined again using the new intensity data generated by SQUEEZE. Statistics prior to treatment of data with SQUEEZE were R1 = 0.1262 (I > 2σ(I)), wR2 = 0.3422 (all data), and S = 1.122.

Synthesis and Structural Characterization. It is well recognized that the crystal engineering of coordination polymers with desired structures and specific properties still remains a difficult challenge, since there are a variety of factors influencing the self-assembly process such as the coordination geometry and the oxidation state of the metal ions, metal-to-ligand ratio, solvents and/or counteranions. Indeed, it was not easy to prepare an analogous compound of 1, which was obtained by the slow diffusion of H2bdc and Cu(NO3)2 with a molar ratio of 2.2:1 in the presence of pyridine, by simply mixing 1,3-H2bdc and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. By changing the molar ratio of H2bdc and Cu(NO3)2 into 1:1 in a dmf, water, and ethanol mixture, as well as introducing benzimidazole as a weak base for slow deprotonation of H2bdc into bdc2- for bridging the metal ions, we finally succeeded in isolating the new coordination polymer of 2·g in good yield and in a shorter period of crystallization, which is different from the preparation of 1. Therefore, we assume that the basicity of the reaction mixture is the most critical factor in governing the formation of 2·g, and benzimidazole is a nice buffering agent. Moreover, it is large enough, in comparison to py, to preclude the possibility of being accommodated in the channel and/or ligated to the apical positions. Therefore, the apical positions of the Cu(II) ions are now occupied by the solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis and Structural Characterization. It is well recognized that the crystal engineering of coordination polymers with desired structures and specific properties still remains a difficult challenge, since there are a variety of factors influencing the self-assembly process such as the coordination geometry and the oxidation state of the metal ions, metal-to-ligand ratio, solvents and/or counteranions. Indeed, it was not easy to prepare an analogous compound of 1, which was obtained by the slow diffusion of H2bdc and Cu(NO3)2 with a molar ratio of 2.2:1 in the presence of pyridine, by simply mixing 1,3-H2bdc and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. By changing the molar ratio of H2bdc and Cu(NO3)2 into 1:1 in a dmf, water, and ethanol mixture, as well as introducing benzimidazole as a weak base for slow deprotonation of H2bdc into bdc2- for bridging the metal ions, we finally succeeded in isolating the new coordination polymer of 2⋅g in good yield and in a shorter period of crystallization, which is different from the preparation of 1. Therefore, we assume that the basicity of the reaction mixture is the most critical factor in governing the formation of 2⋅g, and benzimidazole is a nice buffering agent. Moreover, it is large enough, in comparison to py, to preclude the possibility of being accommodated in the channel and/or ligated to the apical positions. Therefore, the apical positions of the Cu(II) ions are now occupied by the solvent molecules.

elements.content: In 2·g, each Cu(II) ion is square-pyramidally coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms at the basal positions and one solvent molecule at the apical position. Each pair of Cu(II) ions is bridged by four carboxylate groups to generate a dinuclear SBUs, whereas four adjacent SBUs are interlinked into a bowl-shaped structural unit [Cu2(bdc)2]4 (Figure ) via the bridging bdc ligands, resulting in an undulating layer structure perpendicular to the c-axis. Each bowl has an outer diameter of 9.4 Å and a depth of 8.4 Å, where the lattice water and dmf molecules are accommodated. The metal−organic layer is very similar to that of 1. However, the three crystallographically independent Cu1, Cu2, and Cu3 ions in 2·g are each linked to a small, and possibly labile, terminal ligand:  ethanol, water, or dmf (Figure S3, Supporting Information), where the longest apical Cu−O bond is associated with the dmf [2.121(8) Å] and is slightly longer that those associated with the ethanol [2.080(8) Å] and aqua [2.120(8) Å] ligands. The adjacent layers are stacked in a slipped fashion (Figure a), giving rise to rhombic channels with an effective dimension of ca. 9.4 × 5.6 Å2 running slanted by ca. 30° to the c-axis and saddle-like channels ca. 4.0 × 3.4 Å2 running along the b-axis, as shown in Figures b and , respectively. The nearest interlayer Cu···Cu distance is ca. 8.0 Å. The porous structure in 2·g is different from that in 1 due to the different packing fashions. Also interestingly, the interlayer interaction forces are uniquely the van der Waals interactions (Figure ); such phenomenon was also observed in the assembly of organic solid molecules. When these terminal ligands are removed, exposed metal sites are created.
elements.clean_text: In 2⋅g, each Cu(II) ion is square-pyramidally coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms at the basal positions and one solvent molecule at the apical position. Each pair of Cu(II) ions is bridged by four carboxylate groups to generate a dinuclear SBUs, whereas four adjacent SBUs are interlinked into a bowl-shaped structural unit [Cu2(bdc)2]4 (Figure ) via the bridging bdc ligands, resulting in an undulating layer structure perpendicular to the c-axis. Each bowl has an outer diameter of 9.4 Å and a depth of 8.4 Å, where the lattice water and dmf molecules are accommodated. The metal-organic layer is very similar to that of 1. However, the three crystallographically independent Cu1, Cu2, and Cu3 ions in 2⋅g are each linked to a small, and possibly labile, terminal ligand: ethanol, water, or dmf (Figure S3, Supporting Information), where the longest apical Cu-O bond is associated with the dmf [2.121(8) Å] and is slightly longer that those associated with the ethanol [2.080(8) Å] and aqua [2.120(8) Å] ligands. The adjacent layers are stacked in a slipped fashion (Figure a), giving rise to rhombic channels with an effective dimension of ca. 9.4 × 5.6 Å2 running slanted by ca. 30° to the c-axis and saddle-like channels ca. 4.0 × 3.4 Å2 running along the b-axis, as shown in Figures b and , respectively. The nearest interlayer Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance is ca. 8.0 Å. The porous structure in 2⋅g is different from that in 1 due to the different packing fashions. Also interestingly, the interlayer interaction forces are uniquely the van der Waals interactions (Figure ); such phenomenon was also observed  in the assembly of organic solid molecules. When these terminal ligands are removed, exposed metal sites are created.

elements.content: To further understand the porosity of desolvated product 2, a preparative-scale sample of 2·g was heated at 120 °C under vacuum monitored by TGA measurements, showing the loss of one dmf, one water, and half ethanol molecules per formula unit. This result is consistent with the TGA result and the structural information that the ethanol and aqua apical ligands are more labile than the dmf one; hence, one apical dmf molecule is retained in the layer upon being heated up to 238 °C. Taking the removable apical enthanol and aqua ligands, as well as the lattice solvent molecules, into consideration, the free volume of 2 is estimated to be 33.5% of the unit cell volume. Although we cannot characterize the single-crystal structure of desolvated 2 because of the active metal center, as shown by the room-temperature PXRD patterns of 2 and as-synthesized 2·g, two peaks are slightly shifted toward the high angle region by ca. 0.3° (Figure S3, Supporting Information). This fact indicates a slight, relative gliding motion of the layers in 2 during the desolvation, which can be attributed to the weak interlayer van der Waals interactions. Moreover, upon immersion of the desolvated 2 to a mixture of dmf/ethanol/water for 24 h, the solvated sample exhibits a very similar diffraction pattern of the as-prepared 2·g (see Figure S3, Supporting Information), which is indicative of a reversible structural transformation. Therefore, 2·g can be regarded as a dynamic porous material. Meanwhile, our efforts to confirm the single-crystal structure of desolvated 2 were unsuccessful; instead, 2 is very easy to rehydrate into 2·4H2O. X-ray single-crystal diffraction demonstrates that both the layer framework and the packing of 2·4H2O are very similar to those of the as-synthesized 2·g; hence, they are isomorphous with the labile apical ligand, and guest molecules in the pores are now replaced by the water molecules in 2·4H2O (Figure S5, Supporting Information). These facts imply that the open coordination sites on the Cu(II) ions are very active and might serve as potential catalytically active sites for some substrates.

This result is consistent with the TGA result and the structural information that the ethanol and aqua apical ligands are more labile than the dmf one; hence, one apical dmf molecule is retained in the layer upon being heated up to 238 °C. Taking the removable apical enthanol and aqua ligands, as well as the lattice solvent molecules, into consideration, the free volume of 2 is estimated to be 33.5% of the unit cell volume. Although we cannot characterize the single-crystal structure of desolvated 2 because of the active metal center, as shown by the room-temperature PXRD patterns of 2 and as-synthesized 2⋅g, two peaks are slightly shifted toward the high angle region by ca. 0.3° (Figure S3, Supporting Information). This fact indicates a slight, relative gliding motion of the layers in 2 during the desolvation, which can be attributed to the weak interlayer van der Waals interactions. Moreover, upon immersion of the desolvated 2 to a mixture of dmf/ethanol/water for 24 h, the solvated sample exhibits a very similar diffraction pattern of the as-prepared 2⋅g (see Figure S3, Supporting Information), which is indicative of a reversible structural transformation. Therefore, 2⋅g can be regarded as a dynamic porous material. Meanwhile, our efforts to confirm the single-crystal structure of desolvated 2 were unsuccessful; instead, 2 is very easy to rehydrate into 2⋅4H2O. X-ray single-crystal diffraction demonstrates that both the layer framework and the packing of 2⋅4H2O are very similar to those of the as-synthesized 2⋅g; hence, they are isomorphous with the labile apical ligand, and guest molecules in the pores are now replaced by the water molecules in 2⋅4H2O (Figure S5, Supporting Information). These facts imply that the open coordination sites on the Cu(II) ions are very active and might serve as potential catalytically active sites for some substrates.

elements.content: Sorption Properties. To examine the porosity and reactivity, the sorption properties of the desolvated 2 have been performed with N2 gas as well as different volatile organic molecules (methanol and benzene).
elements.clean_text: Sorption Properties. To examine the porosity and reactivity, the sorption properties of the desolvated 2 have been performed with N2 gas as well as different volatile organic molecules (methanol and benzene).

elements.content: The N2 gas sorption isotherm at 77 K shows a typical type I behavior characterized by a plateau reached at low relative pressure (Figure ). With an approximation based on a monolayer condensation of adsorbed N2 molecules on a uniform surface, the sorption isotherm of 2 was fitted to the Langmuir equation and gave a surface area of 629 m2·g-1 (BET surface area, 374 m2·g-1), which is larger than that of another microporous copper(II) framework of MOF-11 (Langmuir surface area, ca. 560 m2·g-1). On the other hand, the micropore filling of gas is well described by the Dudinin- Radushkevich (DR) equation: in which W and W 0 are the amount of adsorption at P/P 0 and the saturated amount of adsorption, respectively. A is the adsorption potential, and β and E 0 are the affinity coefficient and characteristic adsorption energy, respectively. The DR plot shows a linear relationship existing at a higher P/P o region (Figure S8, Supporting Information), from which the value of βE o is obtained. Furthermore, the value of βE o allows the calculation of the isosteric heat of adsorption, q st,Φ =1/ e , at the fractional filling of 1/e using eq 2 where ΔH v is the heat of vaporization of the bulk liquid. The value for ΔH v for N2 at 77 K is 5.58 kJ mol-1, and thus the value of q st,Φ =1/ e of 2 for N2 is 10.7 kJ mol-1, very close to that of activated carbon (ca. 12 kJ mol-1). The sorption isotherm of methanol vapor was measured at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the sorption of 2 for methanol shows gradual increases in the pressure range (P/P 0 = 0.01−0.90) without saturation, and the amount adsorbed is 171 mg·g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.90, which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 3 molecules of methanol per formula unit. On the other hand, the desorption curve does not retrace the adsorption isotherm, showing hysteresis and incomplete desorption (90 mg·g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.006), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 1.5 molecules of methanol per formula unit (one methanol is bound to the open metal site, and the other 0.5 molecule implies a small quality of remaining methanol molecules in the pore). The desorption behavior indicates that chemisorption occurs and methanol molecules may directly coordinate to the unsaturated Cu(II) centers. In addition, according to the DR plot (Figure S9, Supporting Information), eqs 1 and 2, the value of q st,Φ =1/ e of 2 for methanol is 45.2 kJ mol-1, suggesting a relatively strong adsorbent−adsorbate interaction, due to the chemisorption phenomenon.

On the other hand, the micropore filling of gas is well described by the Dudinin- Radushkevich (DR) equation:    in which W and W 0 are the amount of adsorption at P/P 0 and the saturated amount of adsorption, respectively. A is the adsorption potential, and β and E 0 are the affinity coefficient  and characteristic adsorption energy, respectively. Furthermore, the value of βE o allows the calculation of the isosteric heat of adsorption, q st,Φ  =1/  e , at the fractional filling of 1/e using eq 2 where ΔH v is the heat of vaporization of the bulk liquid. The value for ΔH v for N2 at 77 K is 5.58 kJ mol-1, and thus the value of q st,Φ =1/  e  of 2 for N2 is 10.7 kJ mol-1, very close to that of activated carbon (ca. 12 kJ mol-1).    The sorption isotherm of methanol vapor was measured at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the sorption of 2 for methanol shows gradual increases in the pressure range (P/P 0 = 0.01-0.90) without saturation, and the amount adsorbed is 171 mg⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.90, which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 3 molecules of methanol per formula unit. On the other hand, the desorption curve does not retrace the adsorption isotherm, showing hysteresis and incomplete desorption (90 mg⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.006), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 1.5 molecules of methanol per formula unit (one methanol is bound to the open metal site, and the other 0.5 molecule implies a small quality of remaining methanol molecules in the pore). elements.content: N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K. P o = 1 atm.

elements.content: Methanol adsorption (▴) and desorption (▵) isotherms at 298 K.P 0 = saturated vapor pressure.
elements.clean_text: 6  Methanol adsorption (▴) and desorption (▵) isotherms at 298 K.P 0 = saturated vapor pressure.

elements.content: The sorption isotherm of benzene vapor was also measured at room temperature. The amount adsorbed by 2 is 70 m2·g-1 (at P/P 0 = 0.88) (Figure ), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 0.5 molecules of benzene per formula unit. The desorption curve also does not coincide with the adsorption curve, showing large hysteresis and incomplete desorption (53 m2·g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.0008), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 0.36 molecules of benzene per formula unit and corresponds to one benzene molecule fettered in each bowl-shaped cavity. This fact may be attributed to the small pore size, as well as to the fact that the wall of the bowl-shaped cavity is suitable to render π-π or C−H···π interactions between the benzene guest and the phenyl ring of bdc in 2. This deduction is also supported by the fact that, according to the DR plot (Figure S10, Supporting Information), eqs 1 and 2, the value of q st,Φ =1/ e for benzene is 267 kJ mol-1, which is much larger than those of activated carbon (ca. 55 kJ mol-1) and q st,Φ =1/ e for methanol.

The desorption curve also does not coincide with the adsorption curve, showing large hysteresis and incomplete desorption (53 m2⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.0008), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 0.36 molecules of benzene per formula unit and corresponds to one benzene molecule fettered in each bowl-shaped cavity. This fact may be attributed to the small pore size, as well as to the fact that the wall of the bowl-shaped cavity is suitable to render π-π or C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the benzene guest and the phenyl ring of bdc in 2. This deduction is also supported by the fact that, according to the DR plot (Figure S10, Supporting Information), eqs 1 and 2, the value of q st,Φ =1/  e  for benzene is 267 kJ mol-1, which is much larger than those of activated carbon (ca. 55 kJ mol-1) and q st,Φ =1/  e  for methanol.

elements.content: Benzene adsorption (▪) and desorption (□) isotherms at 298 K.P 0 = saturated vapor pressure.
elements.clean_text: 7  Benzene adsorption (▪) and desorption (□) isotherms at 298 K.P 0 = saturated vapor pressure.

elements.content: In addition, the N2 adsorption isotherm on a logarithmic relative pressure is characterized by a large step located at ca. P/P 0 = 10-1.5 (referred to as the gate-opening pressure), which should be attributed to the dynamic feature of framework (Figure a). This phenomenon can also be observed for the methanol and benzene adsorption on 2 (Figure b) and the corresponding relative pressure is 10-4 and 10-1, respectively. Compared with the gate-opening pressure for the N2 adsorption, the lower relative pressure for methanol (molecular size 4.2 Å) is attributed to the strong chemisorption because of the coordinatively unsaturated metal centers in spite of its larger size than N2, whereas the higher relative pressure for benzene (molecular size 3.3 × 6.6 × 7.3 Å3) vapor can be ascribed to the effect of a larger size. Similar dynamic behavior can be found on other porous coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: In addition, the N2 adsorption isotherm on a logarithmic relative pressure is characterized by a large step located at ca. P/P 0 = 10-1.5 (referred to as the gate-opening pressure), which should be attributed to the dynamic feature of framework (Figure a). This phenomenon can also be observed for the methanol and benzene adsorption on 2 (Figure b) and the corresponding relative pressure is 10-4 and 10-1, respectively. Compared with the gate-opening pressure for the N2 adsorption, the lower relative pressure for methanol (molecular size 4.2 Å) is attributed to the strong chemisorption because of the coordinatively  unsaturated metal centers in spite of its larger size than N2, whereas the higher relative pressure for benzene (molecular size 3.3 × 6.6 × 7.3 Å3) vapor can be ascribed to the effect of a larger size. Similar dynamic behavior can be found on other porous coordination polymers.

elements.content: The logarithmic relative pressure expression of adsorption isotherms of (a) N2; (b) methanol (·) and benzene (▪) on solid 2.
elements.clean_text: 8  The logarithmic relative pressure expression of adsorption isotherms of (a) N2; (b) methanol (⋅) and benzene (▪) on solid 2.

elements.content: A new dynamic porous coordination polymer 2 constructed by 2-D layers pillared by van der Waals interactions has been successfully synthesized, which exhibits moderate sorption capabilities for N2 gas and methanol/benzene vapors. More importantly, this material has labile coordination sites that can be activated via heating in vacuo to provide vacant coordination sites for ligating potential ligands, such as ethanol molecules, thus showing adsorption/desorption hysteresis. The results also show a size effect in the sorption of large molecules such as benzene due to its small pore size. Therefore, this work enforces the fact that metal−organic layers can exhibit useful porous structures, in particular, as potential selective gas-sorption and catalytic material based on a pore size effect and active coordination sites.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A new dynamic porous coordination polymer 2 constructed by 2-D layers pillared by van der Waals interactions has been successfully synthesized, which exhibits moderate sorption capabilities for N2 gas and methanol/benzene vapors. More importantly, this material has labile coordination sites that can be activated via heating in vacuo to provide vacant coordination sites for ligating potential ligands, such as ethanol molecules, thus showing adsorption/desorption hysteresis. The results also show a size effect in the sorption of large molecules such as benzene due to its small pore size. Therefore, this work enforces the fact that metal-organic layers can exhibit useful porous structures, in particular, as potential selective gas-sorption and catalytic material based on a pore size effect and active coordination sites.

elements.content: TGA plot for 2·g, asymmetric unit diagrams for 2·g and 2·4H2O, PXRD, IR, Dubinin-Raduskevich plots of N2, methanol and benzene adsorption data, the pore-size distribution for solid 2, and X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

TGA plot for 2⋅g, asymmetric unit diagrams for 2⋅g and 2⋅4H2O, PXRD, IR, Dubinin-Raduskevich plots of N2, methanol and benzene adsorption data, the pore-size distribution for solid 2, and X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.clean_text: References

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of 2·g. An aqueous solution (15 mL) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.122 g, 0.5 mmol) was added to a 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) in a dmf and ethanol mixture (1:1, 30 mL) in the presence of benzimidazole (0.030 g, 0.25 mmol). The resulting solution was filtered and allowed to stand at room temperature. Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after several days (Yield 59%). C23H27Cu2N2O11.5 (642.56):  calcd. C, 42.99; H, 4.24; N, 4.36%. Found:  C, 42.45; H, 4.12; N, 4.54%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3424(w), 2930(w), 1632(vs), 1577(m), 1389(vs), 1104(m), 723(m), 488(m).

Synthesis of 2·4H2O. This compound was produced by exposing desolvated 2 in open air for about 4 h.

TGA and PXRD Characterization. From the TGA results, we found that the observed weight loss (19.6%) at 238 °C for 2·g is reasonably close to calculated values based on elemental analysis (17.8%), corresponding to the removal of guest dmf and water molecules, as well as to the apical water and ethanol ligands (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The PXRD pattern of as-synthesized 2·g is consistent with that simulated using the single-crystal data of 2·g, which confirms the phase purity of the bulk sample of 2·g (Figure S2, Supporting Information).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 2⋅g. An aqueous solution (15 mL) of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.122 g, 0.5 mmol) was added to a 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) in a dmf and ethanol mixture (1:1, 30 mL) in the presence of benzimidazole (0.030 g, 0.25 mmol). The resulting solution was filtered and allowed to stand at room temperature. Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after several days (Yield 59%). C23H27Cu2N2O11.5 (642.56): calcd. C, 42.99; H, 4.24; N, 4.36%. Found: C, 42.45; H, 4.12; N, 4.54%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3424(w), 2930(w), 1632(vs), 1577(m), 1389(vs), 1104(m), 723(m), 488(m). 

 Synthesis of 2⋅4H2O. This compound was produced by exposing desolvated 2 in open air for about 4 h. 

 TGA and PXRD Characterization. From the TGA results, we found that the observed weight loss (19.6%) at 238 °C for 2⋅g is reasonably close to calculated values based on elemental analysis (17.8%), corresponding to the removal of guest dmf and water molecules, as well as to the apical water and ethanol ligands (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The PXRD pattern of as-synthesized 2⋅g is consistent with that simulated using the single-crystal data of 2⋅g, which confirms the phase purity of the bulk sample of 2⋅g (Figure S2, Supporting Information).

cln_elements.content:
The synthesis, crystal structure, and sorption properties of [Cu2(bdc)2(dmf)]H2O·(dmf)(C2H5OH)0.5 (2·g, g = dmf·H2O·(C2H5OH)0.5, bdc = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, dmf = N,N‘-dimethylformamide) are reported. 2·g features upended bowl cavities with an outer diameter of 9.4 Å, which are enclosed by four tetracarboxylate-bridged Cu2 paddle-wheels and extended by dicarboxylate linkers into a two-dimensional (2-D) coordination polymer. The metal−organic layers are further stacked in a slipped manner through van der Waals interactions to generate a three-dimensional (3-D) supramolecular structure having 2-D channels that accommodate the solvent molecules. After removal of the solvent molecules, solid 2 exhibits permanent porosity verified by an N2 sorption isotherm with a Langmuir surface area of 629 m2·g-1 and Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of 374 m2·g-1. Moreover, solid 2 also displays interesting methanol and benzene vapor sorption behaviors with large hysteresis and incomplete desorption, which is attributed to the chemisorption.

The N2 gas sorption isotherm at 77 K shows a typical type I behavior characterized by a plateau reached at low relative pressure (Figure ). With an approximation based on a monolayer condensation of adsorbed N2 molecules on a uniform surface, the sorption isotherm of 2 was fitted to the Langmuir equation and gave a surface area of 629 m2·g-1 (BET surface area, 374 m2·g-1), which is larger than that of another microporous copper(II) framework of MOF-11 (Langmuir surface area, ca. 560 m2·g-1). On the other hand, the micropore filling of gas is well described by the Dudinin- Radushkevich (DR) equation: in which W and W 0 are the amount of adsorption at P/P 0 and the saturated amount of adsorption, respectively. A is the adsorption potential, and β and E 0 are the affinity coefficient and characteristic adsorption energy, respectively. The DR plot shows a linear relationship existing at a higher P/P o region (Figure S8, Supporting Information), from which the value of βE o is obtained. Furthermore, the value of βE o allows the calculation of the isosteric heat of adsorption, q st,Φ =1/ e , at the fractional filling of 1/e using eq 2 where ΔH v is the heat of vaporization of the bulk liquid. The value for ΔH v for N2 at 77 K is 5.58 kJ mol-1, and thus the value of q st,Φ =1/ e of 2 for N2 is 10.7 kJ mol-1, very close to that of activated carbon (ca. 12 kJ mol-1). The sorption isotherm of methanol vapor was measured at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the sorption of 2 for methanol shows gradual increases in the pressure range (P/P 0 = 0.01−0.90) without saturation, and the amount adsorbed is 171 mg·g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.90, which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 3 molecules of methanol per formula unit. On the other hand, the desorption curve does not retrace the adsorption isotherm, showing hysteresis and incomplete desorption (90 mg·g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.006), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 1.5 molecules of methanol per formula unit (one methanol is bound to the open metal site, and the other 0.5 molecule implies a small quality of remaining methanol molecules in the pore). The desorption behavior indicates that chemisorption occurs and methanol molecules may directly coordinate to the unsaturated Cu(II) centers. In addition, according to the DR plot (Figure S9, Supporting Information), eqs 1 and 2, the value of q st,Φ =1/ e of 2 for methanol is 45.2 kJ mol-1, suggesting a relatively strong adsorbent−adsorbate interaction, due to the chemisorption phenomenon.

The sorption isotherm of benzene vapor was also measured at room temperature. The amount adsorbed by 2 is 70 m2·g-1 (at P/P 0 = 0.88) (Figure ), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 0.5 molecules of benzene per formula unit. The desorption curve also does not coincide with the adsorption curve, showing large hysteresis and incomplete desorption (53 m2·g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.0008), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 0.36 molecules of benzene per formula unit and corresponds to one benzene molecule fettered in each bowl-shaped cavity. This fact may be attributed to the small pore size, as well as to the fact that the wall of the bowl-shaped cavity is suitable to render π-π or C−H···π interactions between the benzene guest and the phenyl ring of bdc in 2. This deduction is also supported by the fact that, according to the DR plot (Figure S10, Supporting Information), eqs 1 and 2, the value of q st,Φ =1/ e for benzene is 267 kJ mol-1, which is much larger than those of activated carbon (ca. 55 kJ mol-1) and q st,Φ =1/ e for methanol.

The metal-organic layers are further stacked in a slipped manner through van der Waals interactions to generate a three-dimensional (3-D) supramolecular structure having 2-D channels that accommodate the solvent molecules. After removal of the solvent molecules, solid 2 exhibits permanent porosity verified by an N2 sorption isotherm with a Langmuir surface area of 629 m2⋅g-1 and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 374 m2⋅g-1. Moreover, solid 2 also displays interesting methanol and benzene vapor sorption behaviors with large hysteresis and incomplete desorption, which is attributed to the chemisorption. 

The N2 gas sorption isotherm at 77 K shows a typical type I behavior characterized by a plateau reached at low relative pressure (Figure ). With an approximation based on a monolayer condensation of adsorbed N2 molecules on a uniform surface, the sorption isotherm of 2 was fitted to the Langmuir equation and gave a surface area of 629 m2⋅g-1 (BET surface area, 374 m2⋅g-1), which is larger than that of another microporous copper(II) framework of MOF-11 (Langmuir surface area, ca. 560 m2⋅g-1). On the other hand, the micropore filling of gas is well described by the Dudinin- Radushkevich (DR) equation:    in which W and W 0 are the amount of adsorption at P/P 0 and the saturated amount of adsorption, respectively. A is the adsorption potential, and β and E 0 are the affinity coefficient  and characteristic adsorption energy, respectively. The DR plot shows a linear relationship existing at a higher P/P o region (Figure S8, Supporting Information), from which the value of βE o is obtained. Furthermore, the value of βE o allows the calculation of the isosteric heat of adsorption, q st,Φ  =1/  e , at the fractional filling of 1/e using eq 2 where ΔH v is the heat of vaporization of the bulk liquid. The value for ΔH v for N2 at 77 K is 5.58 kJ mol-1, and thus the value of q st,Φ =1/  e  of 2 for N2 is 10.7 kJ mol-1, very close to that of activated carbon (ca. 12 kJ mol-1).    The sorption isotherm of methanol vapor was measured at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the sorption of 2 for methanol shows gradual increases in the pressure range (P/P 0 = 0.01-0.90) without saturation, and the amount adsorbed is 171 mg⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.90, which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 3 molecules of methanol per formula unit. The desorption behavior indicates that chemisorption occurs and methanol molecules may directly coordinate to the unsaturated Cu(II) centers. In addition, according to the DR plot (Figure S9, Supporting Information), eqs 1 and 2, the value of q st,Φ =1/  e  of 2 for methanol is 45.2 kJ mol-1, suggesting a relatively strong adsorbent-adsorbate interaction, due to the chemisorption phenomenon.   

The sorption isotherm of benzene vapor was also measured at room temperature. The amount adsorbed by 2 is 70 m2⋅g-1 (at P/P 0 = 0.88) (Figure ), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 0.5 molecules of benzene per formula unit. The desorption curve also does not coincide with the adsorption curve, showing large hysteresis and incomplete desorption (53 m2⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.0008), which is equivalent to the adsorption of approximately 0.36 molecules of benzene per formula unit and corresponds to one benzene molecule fettered in each bowl-shaped cavity. This fact may be attributed to the small pore size, as well as to the fact that the wall of the bowl-shaped cavity is suitable to render π-π or C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the benzene guest and the phenyl ring of bdc in 2. This deduction is also supported by the fact that, according to the DR plot (Figure S10, Supporting Information), eqs 1 and 2, the value of q st,Φ =1/  e  for benzene is 267 kJ mol-1, which is much larger than those of activated carbon (ca. 55 kJ mol-1) and q st,Φ =1/  e  for methanol.
